intro: Allium yilandaghense, commonly known as the Yilandagh garlic, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the high-altitude regions of Turkey. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its compact rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces a single, elongated purple flower stem that bears small, white or pale purple flowers. Its botanical features make it an important species for botanical research and conservation efforts. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered vulnerable to environmental changes.
